Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of Harpocrates wearing the double crown of Egypt over a mass of curley hair. Forefinger of right hand at mouth. Head only. Mould-made and hollow. White coating. Red-brown Nile silt fabric. Abundant mica, quartz, organic and white inclusions.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

A number of similar mould series have been found at Naukratis and were likely made there (Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology NA660, NA663; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-G.105; see also NA664 and AN1896-1908-E.4689, but with additional lotus buds). Parallel from 2nd century AD context at Tell Atrib (Szymańska 2005, no.120). Unprovenanced parallel has been dated to the early 1st century AD (Török 1995, no.93) and other 'Roman' parallels exist (Dunand 1990, no. 316-7). However, a 2nd century BC parallel was found at Tell Atrib (Szymańska 2005, no. 203). Szymańska, H. 2005, Terres cuites d’Athribis, Turnhout. Török, L. 1995, Hellenistic and Roman Terracottas from Egypt, Roma.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.096) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4590 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
